bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Siler, January 20, 1953

div1.p: Hench informs Siler that Elmore represented the Walter Reed Memorial Association at the Camp Lazear dedication.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Siler, January 20, 1953
div1.opener:
January 20, 1953
Colonel J. F. Siler, President
Walter Reed Memorial Association
1835 Eye Street N.W.
Washington 6, D. C.
My dear Colonel Siler:
div1.p:
Permit me to send to you as President of the Walter Reed Memorial Associa-
tion, a copy of a long letter which was written primarily for relatives of those
honored at the dedication of Camp Lazear. I think a copy should be in the
files of the Walter Reed Memorial Association. If per chance you or General
Love should wish an extra copy, we could have them made for you as they are
ozalid copies.

It was extremely important to have the Walter Reed Memorial Association
represented on this occasion. I had intended to give myself the honor of
placing the wreath for the Association but because of the absence of General
Streit and one or two others I had to place two wreaths before that of the
Walter Reed Memorial Association was to be placed. Therefore an even better
representative for the Association was provided by Ambassador Beaulac in the
person of Lt. Colonel Vincent M. Elmore, Army Attache of the U. S. Embassy
in Cuba. In view of the military rank of Walter Reed, it was more appropriate
to have Colonel Elmore place the wreath than to have a civilian do this.

The cost of each wreath was $15. They were really very lovely and would
have cost two or three times that much here. They were purchased from
“Milagros Flores,” Lucila Schumann, President, who gave me only one bill
itemizing each wreath and institutional donor. If you need an ozalid copy
I can send it. Otherwise I should be glad to receive a check for $15 at your
convenience.

I realize that the Walter Reed Memorial Association has limited funds which
should be reserved almost exclusively for the present purposed but I think
that our association should have a fairly complete list of the photographs.
Quite a few were taken of various parts of the ceremony, perhaps 50 or so. I
shall try to borrow all of the films and present to the Association at least
small copies of each. These only cost a few cents each but at the moment
(facing the ides of March and the tax collector) I do not believe I can send
you 50 enlargements which would run to $75 or so but I do want you, General
Love, the Reeds and Mrs. Kean to see the pictures.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
